content: Very interesting article about counterinsurgency warfare at the very lowest level in Afghanistan. Highly complementary of the Marines involved, IMO: "This is Firebase Vimoto, named for Pfc. Timothy R. Vimoto, an American soldier killed in the valley two years ago. If all goes according to the Pentagon’s plan, this tiny perimeter — home to an Afghan platoon and two Marine Corps infantrymen — contains the future of Afghanistan." ***http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/30508543//***

content: One of the remote observation points near my FOB in Afghanistan was run by Pakistani/Afghan security forces. One day, the Taliban took over the O.P. using small arms fire and a few grenades. There were no casualties. They all just simply ran away. After they diteched their uniforms and weapons. So, fast forward a few days later when an American team goes up to check on the O.P., and sure enough, they are ambushed and several are killed. It took us a while to figure out what happened. Most of the guys that were manning the O.P. where just chilling at their homes when we found them after the incident. I could go on...........................

content: quote: http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/30508543 The 'fight' is in local hands already. And other than teaching the Afghans to use computer directed communications systems or armaments, there probably isn't an awful lot a 25-year old Marine from upstate New York could teach Afghans about fighting Afghans. They've been doing that, at least in the latest 'go round', since 'junior' was in nappies. They seem to have some facility - call it trial and error - in becoming pretty proficient with fairly high technology all by themselves. Needless to say their low-tech approach has caused the most advanced armies to 're-think'. Just what is we're teaching them? >http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/LAC.20090501.AFGHAN01ART2130/TPStory/TPInternational/Asia/
